elements.content: In recent years, heterogeneous catalysis has become one of the most active domains in the research of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs). Here, two three-dimensional (3D) Co­(II)-MOFs with open metal sites and exposed azo functionality on the MOF backbone have been constructed via mixed ligand assembly. Both the MOFs, 1 {[Co2(1,4-NDC)2(L)­(H2O)2(μ2-H2O)]·(DMF)2(H2O)} n and 2 {[Co­(fma)­(L)­(H2O)2]·S} n [1,4-NDC = 1,4-naphthalene dicarboxylic acid, fma = fumaric acid, L = 3,3′-azobis pyridine and S = disordered solvents] exhibit 3D frameworks with metal-bound aqua ligands. These metal-bound aqua ligands, as well as the lattice solvent molecules, could simply be removed upon activation affording the desolvated frameworks 1a and 2a respectively maintaining the original crystallinity with a varying number of open metal sites. Although crystallographic analysis revealed a porous structure for both the MOFs (34.4% and 14.3% void volume for 1 and 2, respectively), 1 showed a permanently microporous nature with a Brunauer–Emmett–Teller surface area of 197 m2 g–1 and moderate CO2 uptake capacity as established through a gas sorption study. Both MOFs exhibit efficient catalytic activity for the chemical fixation of CO2 to cyclic carbonate in the presence of a cocatalyst, cyanosilylation reaction, and Knoevenagel condensation under solvent-free and mild conditions and thus demonstrating their multipurpose heterogeneous catalytic nature. The limited pore space decorated with the exposed metal sites and the functional azo groups were efficient for size-selective heterogeneous catalysis with varying catalytic efficiencies. A systematic comparison in their catalytic performances could be made with the establishment of a structure–function relationship. Besides, both MOFs can easily be separated out from the reaction mixtures and reused for at least four cycles without any loss of catalytic activity and structural integrity.

elements.content: Two new three-dimensional Co­(II)-metal−organic frameworks with varying porosities and open metal sites have been constructed for three different types of heterogeneous catalysis such as a CO2 to cyclic carbonate, cyanosilylation reaction and Knoevenagel condensation under solvent-free and mild conditions.
elements.clean_text: Two new three-dimensional Co(II)-metal-organic frameworks with varying porosities and open metal sites have been constructed for three different types of heterogeneous catalysis such as a CO2 to cyclic carbonate, cyanosilylation reaction and Knoevenagel condensation under solvent-free and mild conditions.

elements.content:
Published as part of a Crystal Growth and Design virtual special issue on the Structure Property Relationship in Crystalline Solids

Introduction

Metal–organic framework (MOFs) have received extensive attention as porous hybrid materials owing to their unique structural features and useful applications ranging from gas storage, separation, catalysis, chemical sensing, drug delivery, magnetism, proton conduction, and so on. Usually, MOFs are constructed from linear or bent poly­(carboxylic acid), which acts as a linker between metal ions or their cluster to give the final three-dimensional (3D) porous structure. In general, the structural arrangement of the building unit and the subsequent overall framework topology play a key role in the bulk property of the particular system. In recent years, MOFs having well-defined crystal structures, modifiable pore topology, excellent tailorability, and high surface areas have presented a huge potential, especially in the field of heterogeneous catalysis. The catalytic property of MOFs can be readily controlled by the proper selection of metal ion and organic ligands. On the basis of the literature reports, there are different types of active sites in the MOF that can catalyze the heterogeneous catalysis reactions (structural defect site, Lewis acid center, open metal site, and MOFs with a functional linker).

Published as part of a Crystal Growth and Design virtual special issue on the Structure Property Relationship in Crystalline Solids

Introduction

Metal-organic framework (MOFs) have received extensive attention as porous hybrid materials owing to their unique structural features and useful applications ranging from gas storage, separation, catalysis, chemical sensing, drug delivery, magnetism, proton conduction, and so on. Usually, MOFs are constructed from linear or bent poly(carboxylic acid), which acts as a linker between metal ions or their cluster to give the final three-dimensional (3D) porous structure. In general, the structural arrangement of the building unit and the subsequent overall framework topology play a key role in the bulk property of the particular system. In recent years, MOFs having well-defined crystal structures, modifiable pore topology, excellent tailorability, and high surface areas have presented a huge potential, especially in the field of heterogeneous catalysis. The catalytic property of MOFs can be readily controlled by the proper selection of metal ion and organic ligands. On the basis of the literature reports, there are different types of active sites in the MOF that can catalyze the heterogeneous catalysis reactions (structural defect site, Lewis acid center, open metal site, and MOFs with a functional linker).

elements.content: There are two fundamental aspects of CO2 related research: sequestration and its utilization. While sequestration deals with CO2 gas separation and storage with porous materials, utilization of CO2 is focused on its chemical reactions as C1 feedstock. The increasing level of CO2 in the atmosphere has encouraged researchers to determine ways to selectively capture CO2 from various sources of gas mixtures, in particular, separation from landfill or biogas (50% CO2 and 50% CH4) and flue gas (15% CO2 and 85% N2). On the other hand, CO2 is an abundant C1 resource, and its chemical conversion to a value-added product such as dimethyl carbonate, N,N′ disubstituted urea, cyclic carbonate, urethanes, formic acid, and so on are both environmentally and practically attractive. Therefore, the formation of cyclic carbonates via metal-catalyzed cycloaddition of CO2 and epoxide has attracted immense attention among the catalysis community. Cyclic carbonates are relatively valuable as pharmaceutical/fine chemicals intermediates in addition to their various biomedical applications. The 100% atom economic ring extension reaction of epoxide with CO2 generating cyclic carbonates is a conventional and well-known procedure catalyzed by a collection of numerous homo- and heterogeneous catalysts such as Schiff base, simple metal oxide, salen complex, and supported ionic liquids catalyst. There are several MOFs reported catalyzing such reactions that required high pressure (>2 MPa) and high temperature (>80 °C) and thus high energy costs. However, under milder conditions, only a handful of MOFs such as MMFC-2, MMPF-9, and HKUST-1 effectively catalyze a such reaction. Therefore, the development of MOFs as a heterogeneous catalyst to produce cyclic carbonates under milder condition is highly desired.

elements.content: Besides CO2 cycloaddition, cyanosilylation is another important organic reaction to produce cyanohydrins from aldehydes, which are major organic compounds for both biological processes and synthetic chemistry as well. They can readily be altered into essential species such as β-amino alcohols or α-hydroxycarboxylic acids. On the other hand, Knoevenagel condensation (condensation between carbonyl compounds and activated methylene compounds) is one of the fundamental reactions in order to form carbon–carbon bonds. This kind of reaction is extensively used for the production of vital drug intermediates. The homogeneous catalysts such as metal oxides or amines are frequently used to catalyze such reactions; however, they do have their inherent limitations. The problem related to homogeneous catalyst essentially includes recycling of the catalyst and the difficulty in separation of the product. Hence, the development of efficient heterogeneous MOF catalysts featuring reusability and easier separation together with nonleaching properties toward multipurpose reactions such as CO2 cycloaddition, cyanosilylation, and Knoevenagel condensation of aldehydes is of great interest that deserves to be explored.

elements.content: On the other hand, it would be preferable to carry out the catalysis reactions without the presence of solvents, simply by using liquid substrates and reagents. Solvent-free environments are favorable not only to avoid releases of organic vapors into the atmosphere, but also the solid catalyst is easily reusable without any byproduct.

elements.content: Considering all those points, we have designed and assembled two 3D Co­(II)-based MOFs bearing open metal sites, from mixed ligand assembly of two acid ligands and a 3,3′-azobis pyridine spacer bearing azo functionality, for their potential usage in multipurpose heterogeneous catalysis. Both the MOFs contain unsaturated Co­(II) center(s) to act as Lewis acidic sites and the accessible azo groups of the spacer to serve as a Lewis base center. Interestingly, as an ideal Lewis acid–base bifunctional catalyst, both the MOFs offer great performance in various scopes of substrates with satisfactory recyclability in three different types of catalysis: CO2 to cyclic carbonate, cyanosilylation reaction, and Knoevenagel condensation in a solvent-free condition. Varying the number of open metal sites, accessible pore volumes, permanent porosity, and CO2 sorption capability enabled us to establish a structure–catalytic function relationship. Although a variety of MOFs have been explored for their various highly efficient catalytic performances, most of them are reported to catalyze single or at most two reactions simultaneously; however, to the best of our knowledge, reports on MOFs toward multipurpose heterogeneous catalysis are yet to be reported.

Experimental Section

Materials and Reagents

The spacer L was prepared according to a previously reported method. All the chemicals used in this work were commercially available and of reagent grade quality and used as received without additional purifications.

elements.content: A mixture of Co­(NO3)2·6H2O (0.1 mmol, 0.029 g), 1,4-NDC (0.1 mmol, 0.0216 g), and linker L (0.05 mmol, 0.009 g) was taken in a mixed solvent (DMF/MeOH/water 1:2:1) was heated to 120 °C under autogenous pressure in a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave for 48 h, followed by slow cooling to room temperature at 5°/min to give 1 as pink, block-shaped crystals in 70% yield based on the metal. Elemental analysis for C40H42CoN6O14, calcd: C, 53.99%; H, 4.76%; N, 9.45%. Found: C, 54.01%; H, 4.75%; N, 9.43%. FT-IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3350.1­(br), 3070.2­(w), 2920.6­(w), 1613.2(s), 1453.7­(m), 1425.9(s), 1355.2(s), 1251.4­(m), 1083.7­(m), 1014.3­(m), 783.9­(m), 686.1­(m), 637.8­(w), 588.4­(m), 445.5­(m).

elements.content: A mixture of Co­(NO3)2·6H2O (0.1 mmol, 0.029 g), fumaric acid (fma) (0.1 mmol, 0.011 g), and linker L (0.05 mmol, 0.009 g) was taken in 3 mL of DMF solution and stirred for 1 h at room temperature. The solution was filtered and kept for slow evaporation at ambient temperature. Red crystals were obtained after 15 days in 60% yield based on the metal. elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray analysis shows that 1 crystallizes in a monoclinic crystal system with space group P21/n constructing a 3D polymeric framework formulated as {[Co2(1,4-NDC)2(L)­(H2O)2(μ2-H2O)]­·(DMF)2(H2O)} n . The primary building unit consists of two cobalt­(II) ions (Co(1) and Co(2)), two 1,4-NDC anions, one spacer (L), one bridging water molecule (μ2-H2O), two coordinated water molecules, two lattice DMF molecules, and one water molecule. As illustrated in a, Co(1) is six-coordinated by four carboxyl oxygen atom from 1,4-NDC, one O atom from μ2-H2O, and one pyridyl N atom from spacer L to complete a distorted octahedral geometry. The bond distances and bond angles around the metal centers in 1 are in the normal range and are listed in Table S2, Supporting Information. Co(2) is also six-coordinated by two chelating carboxylate groups, two coordinated water molecules (Ow1 and Ow2), one pyridyl N atom, and one O atom from μ2-H2O. Two Co­(II) ions are bridged by two bis (monodentate) carboxyl groups and one aqua ligand with μ2 bridging mode forming a dimeric {Co2(COO)4} unit with a two-dimensional (2D) square-shaped layered network (b). The 2D layered network is further connected by the spacer (L) to generate an extended 3D network (c). The separation distance between the two Co­(II) metal centers along Co(1)···L···Co(1) and Co(2)···L···Co(2) are 10.832 and 12.007 Å, respectively. The framework contains a total 34.4% solvent-accessible volume (1484.0 Å3 of the unit cell volume of 4308.9 Å3) as estimated through PLATON calculations with the formation of a channel (5.0 × 8.2 Å2 considering van der Waals radii) along the crystallographic “a” axis (c). Topological analysis of 1 using TOPOS reveals that the framework of 1 can be simplified to a 3D uninodal 6-connected rob topology with the point symbol {48.66.8} as depicted in d. Several H-bonding interactions among solvent molecules and the constituent ligands further stabilize the framework (Table S3, Supporting Information).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Single-crystal X-ray analysis shows that 1 crystallizes in a monoclinic crystal system with space group P21/n constructing a 3D polymeric framework formulated as {[Co2(1,4-NDC)2(L)(H2O)2(μ2-H2O)]⋅(DMF)2(H2O)} n . The primary building unit consists of two cobalt(II) ions (Co(1) and Co(2)), two 1,4-NDC anions, one spacer (L), one bridging water molecule (μ2-H2O), two coordinated water molecules, two lattice DMF molecules, and one water molecule. As illustrated in a, Co(1) is six-coordinated by four carboxyl oxygen atom from 1,4-NDC, one O atom from μ2-H2O, and one pyridyl N atom from spacer L to complete a distorted octahedral geometry. The bond distances and bond angles around the metal centers in 1 are in the normal range and are listed in Table S2, Supporting Information. Co(2) is also six-coordinated by two chelating carboxylate groups, two coordinated water molecules (Ow1 and Ow2), one pyridyl N atom, and one O atom from μ2-H2O. Two Co(II) ions are bridged by two bis (monodentate) carboxyl groups and one aqua ligand with μ2 bridging mode forming a dimeric {Co2(COO)4} unit with a two-dimensional (2D) square-shaped layered network (b). The 2D layered network is further connected by the spacer (L) to generate an extended 3D network (c). The separation distance between the two Co(II) metal centers along Co(1)⋅⋅⋅L⋅⋅⋅Co(1) and Co(2)⋅⋅⋅L⋅⋅⋅Co(2) are 10.832 and 12.007 Å, respectively. The framework contains a total 34.4% solvent-accessible volume (1484.0 Å3 of the unit cell volume of 4308.9 Å3) as estimated through PLATON calculations with the formation of a channel (5.0 × 8.2 Å2 considering van der Waals radii) along the crystallographic "a" axis (c). Topological analysis of 1 using TOPOS reveals that the framework of 1 can be simplified to a 3D uninodal 6-connected  rob  topology with the point symbol {48.66.8} as depicted in d. Several H-bonding interactions among solvent molecules and the constituent ligands further stabilize the framework (Table S3, Supporting Information).

elements.content: The single-crystal X-ray determination of the structure for 2 also reveals a 3D coordination framework constituted by fma2– and a N,N′-donor spacer L. 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system with C2/c space group formulated as {[Co­(fma)­(L)­(H2O)2]·S} n . The asymmetric unit of 2 consists of one-half of the Co­(II) metal ion, half deprotonated fumaric acid, half of the L spacer, and one coordinated water molecule. Each Co­(II) atom is six-coordinated with two N atoms ligated from two different L spacer in the axial position and four O atoms, among them two from symmetry-related water molecules and two different fma2– units and thus giving rise to a distorted octahedral configuration {CoO4N2} (a). The Co–O bond distances range from 2.067 to 2.075 Å, whereas the Co–N bond distance is 2.173 Å, which are in the normal range and are listed in Table S4, Supporting Information. The Co­(II) ions are coordinated by fumarate dianion and N,N′-donor spacer L in an alternating fashion to form a 2D [Co­(fma)­(L)] network (b). These 2D layers are further pillared by spacer L, generating a 3D pillar-layered framework that houses 1D channels with an approximate diameter of 3.6 Å, which is much smaller in size than found in 1 (c). The PLATON calculation after removing the disordered solvent molecule indicates that 2 affords a porosity of 14.3% of unit cell volume (254.6 Å3 per unit cell volume of 1776.5 Å3), which is again substantially lower than the 34.4% porosity found in 1. The framework of 2 can be simplified to a 3D uninodal, 4-connected cds topology with the point symbol {65.8} as depicted in d. One H-bonding and one noncovalent intermolecular interactions among the ligands further stabilized the framework (Table S5, Supporting Information).

elements.content: To investigate the purity of the crystals in the bulk phase, a powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) experiment was carried out for both samples. The PXRD pattern of bulk samples of both cases is in good agreement with the as-synthesized ones, suggesting the phase purity in bulk synthesis (Figures S1–S2, Supporting Information). It is well-known that chemical stability is essential for the intended practical applications. To illustrate the chemical stability of both MOFs, the PXRD patterns were recorded after immersing the MOFs in various solvents such as MeOH, THF, acetone, acetonitrile, and water for 24 h. 1 shows high stability in common organic solvents; however, when treated in water, a change in peak positions in PXRD patterns is observed, suggesting the formation of a different phase (Figure S3, Supporting Information) probably due to the partial hydrolysis of metal–ligand bonds. On the other hand, for 2, the PXRD pattern of the dried sample after soaking in different solvents including water reveals the exact similarity with the as-synthesized pattern, indicating its high chemical stability (Figure S4, Supporting Information).

elements.content: TGA profile of 1 shows a gradual weight loss up to 175 °C due to the removal of DMF and H2O molecules (calc. 22.5% for two lattice DMF and one water; three coordinated water molecules). The network is stable until 270 °C and after that, a steady decomposition could be observed. On the other hand, the framework of 2 shows a gradual weight loss up to 150 °C due to the elimination of disordered lattice solvent as well as metal-bound H2O molecules followed by steady weight loss corresponding to the degradation of the framework (Figure S5, Supporting Information).

elements.content: The permanent porosity of the MOFs was investigated by gas sorption studies. Before gas sorption measurement, as-synthesized MOFs were exchanged with dry chloroform for 48 h (10 times) and then subsequently activated at 373 K under a high vacuum for 14 h. The activated frameworks retained the original crystallinity as confirmed through PXRD analysis (Figures S1–S2, Supporting Information). It was found that the activated samples of 1 and 2 (1a and 2a respectively) do not adsorb any N2 at 77 K, indicating the energy of adsorbate and the thermal energy of the framework are not high enough to permit the diffusion of the adsorbate molecule through the pores. It is also well-known that at this temperature the diffusion of nitrogen through the micropores of the framework is very sluggish, and diffusional limitation at this temperature may influence the adsorption in ultramicropores. However, 1a adsorbed 84 cm3 g–1 of CO2 at 195 K/1 bar, which corresponds to a BET surface area of 197 m2 g–1 (a), thus establishing its permanent microporous nature. On the other hand, 2a did not adsorb CO2 under similar conditions, confirming its non-microporosity and less affinity toward CO2. 1a took up moderate CO2 uptake amount of 1.6 and 1.2 mmol at 273 and 295 K respectively under 1 bar (b), whereas 2a showed negligible uptake under such conditions (Figure S6, Supporting Information).

elements.content: Given the open metal sites in both the MOFs and capacity to adsorb CO2 at ambient conditions for 1, we decided to estimate its performances as a Lewis acid based catalyst in the wide range of heterogeneous catalysis such as cycloaddition of CO2 and epoxides to form cyclic carbonates, cyanosilylation reaction, and Knoevenagel condensation under mild conditions at 1 bar pressure.
elements.clean_text:
Cycloaddition of CO2 to Various Epoxides

Given the open metal sites in both the MOFs and capacity to adsorb CO2 at ambient conditions for 1, we decided to estimate its performances as a Lewis acid based catalyst in the wide range of heterogeneous catalysis such as cycloaddition of CO2 and epoxides to form cyclic carbonates, cyanosilylation reaction, and Knoevenagel condensation under mild conditions at 1 bar pressure.

elements.content: The presence of an open metal site in 1 is very important for CO2 fixation as it is already established that CO2 molecules generally occupy positions near the unsaturated metal centers at low pressure. Moderate CO2 uptake capacity on 1a, the exposed metal sites, as well as Lewis basic sites on both the frameworks of 1 and 2 make these MOFs potential heterogeneous catalysts for cycloaddition reaction of CO2 with a various epoxides. The reaction was performed with styrene oxide, activated catalyst 1a, and tetrabutyl ammonium bromide as a cocatalyst in a two-neck, round-bottom flask at room temperature with a pressure of 1 bar CO2 for 24 h. However, the conversion of the corresponding carbonate was found to be only ∼20%; therefore, the temperature of the reaction mixture was increased stepwise, and finally 80 °C was selected as the optimum temperature. Keeping the temperature fixed at 80 °C, the reaction time was increased successively from 1 h and finally optimized to 12 h (Figure S7, Supporting Information). The conversion of the product from CO2 under this condition was found to be 93%. The catalytic reaction was also investigated in the presence of both spacer and acid ligand; however, no desired product could be obtained. Co­(NO3)2·6H2O was also tested as a catalyst; only a 20% yield was obtained.

Definitely, the capacity of 1a to chemically convert CO2 into cyclic carbonates with high efficiency under mild conditions (i.e., 80 °C and 1 bar CO2 pressure) is highly beneficial. It may be noted that high pressure and high temperature were used to achieve such efficiency for some well-known MOFs. For example, conversions of 98%, 93%, 95%, 53%, and 48% were achieved for MOF-5 (323 K, 60 bar pressure), ZIF-68 (393 K, 10 bar pressure), Mg-MOF-74 (373 K, 20 bar pressure), UMCM-1-NH2 (300 K, 12 bar pressure), and HKUST-1 (373 K, 20 bar pressure) respectively under a relatively higher temperature and higher CO2 pressure (Table S6, Supporting Information). On the other hand, Co-MOFs with open metal sites have been found to achieve >95% conversion for styrene oxide with comparatively higher pressure (2 MPa, 100 °C, 4 h for Co-MOF-74 and 0.8 MPa, 80 °C, 12 h for [{Co­(muco)­(bpa)­(2H2O)}·2H2O] n . In order to gain insight into the scope of the catalysis reactions for MOF 1 and 2, a systematic approach was taken by varying the size of the substrates. As shown in , the substrates with electron-withdrawing group generally showed better conversions. For example, the cycloaddition of CO2 with epichlorohydrin and allylglycidyl ether were effectively catalyzed in high conversions (96% and 87%; 80% and 78%) (Figures S8–S9, Supporting Information). When propylene oxide, styrene oxide, and 1,2-epoxy cyclohexane were used, the desired product was generated with 97% and 90%; 93% and 86%; and 42% and 30% conversions for 1a and 2a respectively (Figures S10–S12, Supporting Information). Interestingly, the smaller size substrates like propylene oxide (4.35 × 3.41 Å2) and styrene epoxide (4.28 × 7.26 Å2) resulted in higher catalytic conversion. On the other side, aliphatic epoxide with a long alkyl chain (, entries 7 and 8) was converted to the cyclic carbonate with low conversion due to the larger size (8.19 × 3.39 and 13.32 × 3.39 Å2), respectively, compared to the pore size (∼5.0 × 8.2 Å2) of 1. The results are in accordance with the fact that small substrates can easily diffuse through the 1D channels which contain large numbers of open metal sites for 1a, suggesting the usefulness of 1a as a promising heterogeneous catalyst for the cycloaddition of CO2. In addition, 2a exhibits a systematically lower catalytic efficiency than 1a, due to its nonaffinity toward CO2 as evident from CO2 sorption studies (Figures S8–S20, Supporting Information). Again, for the case of 2, the 1D channels with an approximate diameter of 3.6 Å is much smaller than the molecular sizes of most of the substrates used in the catalytic reaction, and therefore, it is assumed that the catalytic reaction for the case of 2a might proceed mainly on the surface of the MOF. Although 2a is nonporous to CO2, it showed surface adsorption behavior (Figure S6, Supporting Information). In addition, presence of open metal sites also makes 2a a potential catalyst for cycloaddition of CO2 to various epoxides with obvious lower efficiency than 1a. The characterization of the desired carbonates was performed by the 1H spectra.

Reaction conditions: epoxides (20 mmol, 1 equiv), catalyst (0.5 mol % based on Co­(II)) TBAB (10 mol %). No solvent was added. The conversion was evaluated from the 1H NMR spectra.

In order to confirm the role of open metal sites onto the frameworks toward catalysis, the catalysis reactions have been investigated without activating the MOFs, i.e., 1 and 2. As expected the yield of the catalytic conversion is very low for both the MOFs (55% for 1; 50% for 2). Therefore, this phenomenon confirms the fact that the presence of open metal sites is ultimately necessary to facilitate the catalytic reaction.

elements.content: A tentative mechanism has been proposed for the formation of cyclic carbonates catalyzed by the strong Lewis acid based catalyst of 1a and 2a on the account of some earlier reports, as demonstrated in Scheme S1 (Supporting Information). Moreover, on the basis of a hot filtration test, the catalysts were found to be entirely heterogeneous, revealing no leaching of Co­(II) ions (Figure S21 for 1a, Figure S22 for 2a, Supporting Information).

elements.content: Taking into account the Lewis acidity and open metal sites, both MOFs were also explored as heterogeneous catalysts in the cyanosilylation reaction under solvent-free conditions. The results are summarized in the . Using 1a as catalyst, the conversion reached up to 96%, while for 2a it was 81% for benzaldehyde (Figures S23–S24, Supporting Information). To investigate the scope and limitation of this heterogeneous catalysis reaction, we studied the influence of various substituents at the phenyl ring and found that conversion is very sensitive to the electronic properties of the substituents attached to the phenyl ring (). Aldehydes with an electron-withdrawing group attached to the phenyl ring are much more reactive than the electron-donating group at the phenyl ring (Figures S25–S28, Supporting Information). On the other hand, the shape and size of the substrates influence the % conversion of the products to some extent; for example, the longer hexanal showed significantly lower conversion (57% and 44%) than the other aromatic substrates. As given in , 1a exhibited higher cyanosilylation catalytic activity than 2a. This can be attributed to the microporous nature of 1a as evident from BET surface area analysis as opposed to the nonporous nature of 2a. Although the conversions are systematically lower for 2a than found in 1a as expected, it still could be considered quite high for aromatic aldehydes. This might be due to the porous nature of 2 as determined through crystallographic analysis, although less compared to 1 as estimated from void volume analysis with PLATON (34.4% vs 14.3%). Moreover, the higher catalytic efficiency of 1a could also be correlated to the higher number of active metal sites within the framework (three open metals sites in 1 vs two in 2 per unit formula). To the best of our knowledge, only a few MOFs have been reported to be capable of efficiently catalyzing the cyanosilylation reaction with such efficiency under solvent-free conditions. Furthermore, Table S7 (Supporting Information) provides a comparison of the catalytic performances of MOF 1a and 2a with those for various other MOF-based catalytic systems reported in the literature in terms of time, temperature, and conversion. A proposed mechanism for cyanosilylation reaction of aldehydes catalyzed by 1a is presented in Scheme S2, Supporting Information. A hot filtration test was performed to check the heterogeneity of the catalyst, showing the catalysis reaction is entirely heterogeneous (Figure S29 for 1a, S30 for 2a, Supporting Information).

Cyanosilylation Reaction

Taking into account the Lewis acidity and open metal sites, both MOFs were also explored as heterogeneous catalysts in the cyanosilylation reaction under solvent-free conditions. The results are summarized in the . Using 1a as catalyst, the conversion reached up to 96%, while for 2a it was 81% for benzaldehyde (Figures S23-S24, Supporting Information). To investigate the scope and limitation of this heterogeneous catalysis reaction, we studied the influence of various substituents at the phenyl ring and found that conversion is very sensitive to the electronic properties of the substituents attached to the phenyl ring (). Aldehydes with an electron-withdrawing group attached to the phenyl ring are much more reactive than the electron-donating group at the phenyl ring (Figures S25-S28, Supporting Information). On the other hand, the shape and size of the substrates influence the % conversion of the products to some extent; for example, the longer hexanal showed significantly lower conversion (57% and 44%) than the other aromatic substrates. As given in , 1a exhibited higher cyanosilylation catalytic activity than 2a. This can be attributed to the microporous nature of 1a as evident from BET surface area analysis as opposed to the nonporous nature of 2a. Although the conversions are systematically lower for 2a than found in 1a as expected, it still could be considered quite high for aromatic aldehydes. This might be due to the porous nature of 2 as determined through crystallographic analysis, although less compared to 1 as estimated from void volume analysis with PLATON (34.4% vs 14.3%). Moreover, the higher catalytic efficiency of 1a could also be correlated to the higher number of active metal sites within the framework (three open metals sites in 1 vs two in 2 per unit formula). To the best of our knowledge, only a few MOFs have been reported to be capable of efficiently catalyzing the cyanosilylation reaction with such efficiency under solvent-free conditions. Furthermore, Table S7 (Supporting Information) provides a comparison of the catalytic performances of MOF 1a and 2a with those for various other MOF-based catalytic systems reported in the literature in terms of time, temperature, and conversion. A proposed mechanism for cyanosilylation reaction of aldehydes catalyzed by 1a is presented in Scheme S2, Supporting Information. A hot filtration test was performed to check the heterogeneity of the catalyst, showing the catalysis reaction is entirely heterogeneous (Figure S29 for 1a, S30 for 2a, Supporting Information).

The presence of moderate porosity as revealed through single-crystal structure determination and abundant Lewis basic and open metal sites for both the MOFs inspired us to explore the catalytic reaction for Knoevenagel condensation of an aldehyde with active methylene compound under solvent-free conditions. As shown in , the conversion reached up to above 90% for 2-benzylidenemalonitrile catalyzed by both the MOFs (Figures S31–S32, Supporting Information). To understand whether the catalysis reaction proceeds inside the pore or surface of the MOFs, various substituted aldehyde groups as substrates were taken, extending the scope of the study under similar conditions. As shown in , in the case of a slightly elongated aldehyde, conversion for hexanal was decreased (33% and 31% for 1a and 2a, respectively) significantly compared to smaller aldehydes for both the MOFs. Furthermore, in the presence of the electron-withdrawing group, i.e., p-chloro benzaldehyde and p-nitro benzaldehyde, excellent conversions are achieved (97% and 95%; 99% and 96%) (Figures S33–S34, Supporting Information); however, for electron-donating groups, i.e., p-anisaldehyde and p-methyl benzaldehyde, the conversions were systematically lower (92% and 78%; 94% and 92%) (Figures S35–S36, Supporting Information), which suggests that the electrophilicity of the carbonyl group increases in the former case and is suppressed in the latter case. As assembled in , 1a exhibited a higher catalytic activity than 2a, due to a more porous nature of 1a compared to 2a as determined through crystallographic and BET surface area analysis in conjunction with more accessible open metal sites in 1a compared to 2a. A systematic comparison of catalytic performances between 1a and 2a along with various other literature reports are given in the Table S8 (Supporting Information). Interestingly, both MOFs offer superior catalytic activity with minimal catalytic loadings under mild and solvent-free conditions, thus making them as potential heterogeneous catalysts for the Knoevenagel condensation reaction. A proposed mechanism for 1a-catalyzed Knoevenagel condensation reaction is shown in Scheme S3, Supporting Information. It is assumed that the interaction between Lewis acidic sites (coordinatively unsaturated cobalt center) and the carbonyl group of the aldehyde improves the electrophilic character of the carbonylic carbon atom, thus assisting the attack by malononitrile. Furthermore, hot filtration data supported the heterogeneous nature of the catalyst for the Knoevenagel reaction (Figure S37 for 1a, Figure S38 for 2a, Supporting Information).

Recyclability is a very important issue for heterogeneous catalytic systems. The catalysts could be completely recovered and reused without showing any significant loss of activity at least for four catalytic cycles by simple filtration followed by washing with DMF, ethyl acetate, DCM and subsequently drying in an oven as shown in Figures S39–S41 (Supporting Information). The integrity of frameworks is also retained during multiple cycles as confirmed by PXRD analysis (Figures S42–S43, Supporting Information), thus demonstrating their potential to act as multipurpose heterogeneous catalysts under milder conditions.
elements.clean_text: Recyclability is a very important issue for heterogeneous catalytic systems. The catalysts could be completely recovered and reused without showing any significant loss of activity at least for four catalytic cycles by simple filtration followed by washing with DMF, ethyl acetate, DCM and subsequently drying in an oven as shown in Figures S39-S41 (Supporting Information). The integrity of frameworks is also retained during multiple cycles as confirmed by PXRD analysis (Figures S42-S43, Supporting Information), thus demonstrating their potential to act as multipurpose heterogeneous catalysts under milder conditions.

elements.content: In conclusion, two new 3D Co­(II)-MOFs with Lewis acid–Lewis base bifunctionalities were successfully developed based on organic dicarboxylic acids and azo-linked N,N′ donor spacers and structurally characterized with varying porosities. The limited pore spaces decorated with exposed metal sites and N-rich functional azo groups were efficient for size-selective chemical transformation of CO2 with epoxide into cyclic carbonate under solvent-free and mild conditions. The MOFs also showed excellent heterogeneous catalytic behavior toward cyanosilylation reactions and Knoevenagel condensation. A systematic comparison in their catalytic performances could be made based on their available open metal site concentrations, porosities, and CO2 sorption capabilities. Apart from these, the catalysts can be easily be separated and reused for at least four cycles without any loss of activity and structural integrity. Given the enormous library of organic poly­(carboxylic acid)­s and N,N′ donor spacers and fewer numbers of reported Co­(II)-based MOFs with permanent porosity and open metal sites, this study may contribute to broaden the scope of Co­(II)-based microporous MOFs for their potential applications in heterogeneous catalysis under mild conditions.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In conclusion, two new 3D Co(II)-MOFs with Lewis acid-Lewis base bifunctionalities were successfully developed based on organic dicarboxylic acids and azo-linked N,N' donor spacers and structurally characterized with varying porosities. The limited pore spaces decorated with exposed metal sites and N-rich functional azo groups were efficient for size-selective chemical transformation of CO2 with epoxide into cyclic carbonate under solvent-free and mild conditions. The MOFs also showed excellent heterogeneous catalytic behavior toward cyanosilylation reactions and Knoevenagel condensation. A systematic comparison in their catalytic performances could be made based on their available open metal site concentrations, porosities, and CO2 sorption capabilities. Apart from these, the catalysts can be easily be separated and reused for at least four cycles without any loss of activity and structural integrity. Given the enormous library of organic poly(carboxylic acid)s and N,N' donor spacers and fewer numbers of reported Co(II)-based MOFs with permanent porosity and open metal sites, this study may contribute to broaden the scope of Co(II)-based microporous MOFs for their potential applications in heterogeneous catalysis under mild conditions.

cln_elements.content:
In recent years, heterogeneous catalysis has become one of the most active domains in the research of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs). Here, two three-dimensional (3D) Co­(II)-MOFs with open metal sites and exposed azo functionality on the MOF backbone have been constructed via mixed ligand assembly. Both the MOFs, 1 {[Co2(1,4-NDC)2(L)­(H2O)2(μ2-H2O)]·(DMF)2(H2O)} n and 2 {[Co­(fma)­(L)­(H2O)2]·S} n [1,4-NDC = 1,4-naphthalene dicarboxylic acid, fma = fumaric acid, L = 3,3′-azobis pyridine and S = disordered solvents] exhibit 3D frameworks with metal-bound aqua ligands. These metal-bound aqua ligands, as well as the lattice solvent molecules, could simply be removed upon activation affording the desolvated frameworks 1a and 2a respectively maintaining the original crystallinity with a varying number of open metal sites. Although crystallographic analysis revealed a porous structure for both the MOFs (34.4% and 14.3% void volume for 1 and 2, respectively), 1 showed a permanently microporous nature with a Brunauer–Emmett–Teller surface area of 197 m2 g–1 and moderate CO2 uptake capacity as established through a gas sorption study. Both MOFs exhibit efficient catalytic activity for the chemical fixation of CO2 to cyclic carbonate in the presence of a cocatalyst, cyanosilylation reaction, and Knoevenagel condensation under solvent-free and mild conditions and thus demonstrating their multipurpose heterogeneous catalytic nature. The limited pore space decorated with the exposed metal sites and the functional azo groups were efficient for size-selective heterogeneous catalysis with varying catalytic efficiencies. A systematic comparison in their catalytic performances could be made with the establishment of a structure–function relationship. Besides, both MOFs can easily be separated out from the reaction mixtures and reused for at least four cycles without any loss of catalytic activity and structural integrity.

TGA profile of 1 shows a gradual weight loss up to 175 °C due to the removal of DMF and H2O molecules (calc. 22.5% for two lattice DMF and one water; three coordinated water molecules). The network is stable until 270 °C and after that, a steady decomposition could be observed. On the other hand, the framework of 2 shows a gradual weight loss up to 150 °C due to the elimination of disordered lattice solvent as well as metal-bound H2O molecules followed by steady weight loss corresponding to the degradation of the framework (Figure S5, Supporting Information).

The permanent porosity of the MOFs was investigated by gas sorption studies. Before gas sorption measurement, as-synthesized MOFs were exchanged with dry chloroform for 48 h (10 times) and then subsequently activated at 373 K under a high vacuum for 14 h. The activated frameworks retained the original crystallinity as confirmed through PXRD analysis (Figures S1–S2, Supporting Information). It was found that the activated samples of 1 and 2 (1a and 2a respectively) do not adsorb any N2 at 77 K, indicating the energy of adsorbate and the thermal energy of the framework are not high enough to permit the diffusion of the adsorbate molecule through the pores. It is also well-known that at this temperature the diffusion of nitrogen through the micropores of the framework is very sluggish, and diffusional limitation at this temperature may influence the adsorption in ultramicropores. However, 1a adsorbed 84 cm3 g–1 of CO2 at 195 K/1 bar, which corresponds to a BET surface area of 197 m2 g–1 (a), thus establishing its permanent microporous nature. On the other hand, 2a did not adsorb CO2 under similar conditions, confirming its non-microporosity and less affinity toward CO2. 1a took up moderate CO2 uptake amount of 1.6 and 1.2 mmol at 273 and 295 K respectively under 1 bar (b), whereas 2a showed negligible uptake under such conditions (Figure S6, Supporting Information).
